perturbation.original_text: eDiets agrees that it will respond in a timely manner to be agreed upon by the parties to all reasonable requests made by Women.com or its agents for updated eDiets Content and refreshing of eDiets Content for the Women.com Sites.
perturbation.changed_text: eDiets agrees that it will respond to requests made by Women.com or its agents for updated eDiets Content and refreshing of eDiets Content for the Women.com Sites within 24 hours.
perturbation.explanation: The original text stipulates a 'timely manner to be agreed upon by the parties,' which is vague. The modified text forces eDiets to respond within 24 hours. Such a short timeframe could be considered unreasonable, depending on the volume and complexity of the requested content updates. This may contradict general contract law principles of 'reasonableness' regarding response times, particularly if the requests are extensive.

perturbation.original_text: Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the Women.com Marks upon seventy-two (72) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.changed_text: Women.com, in its sole discretion, may withdraw specific or general permission to use the Women.com Marks upon twelve (12) hours written notice to eDiets. Upon expiration of such notice period, eDiets shall immediately discontinue use of the applicable Women.com Marks.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows Women.com to withdraw permission to use its marks with 72 hours' notice. The modified text reduces this to 12 hours. This could be considered an unreasonably short notice period, especially if eDiets has substantial marketing materials or campaigns already in progress featuring the marks. It potentially contradicts the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing inherent in contracts, particularly in California, where the contract is governed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (California Law)

perturbation.original_text: Within fifteen (15) days of receipt by Receiving Party of a written request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's instruction. Receiving Party shall then certify the same in writing and that no copies have been retained by Receiving Party, its employees, agents or contractors.
perturbation.changed_text: Upon request from the Disclosing Party for the return of Confidential Information, all Disclosing Party's Confidential Information and all copies thereof in Receiving Party's possession or control shall be returned to Disclosing Party or destroyed by Receiving Party at Disclosing Party's instruction. Receiving Party shall then certify the same in writing and that no copies have been retained by Receiving Party, its employees, agents or contractors.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows for 15 days to return the confidential information. The modified text removes that 15-day grace period, potentially conflicting with California's trade secret laws by compelling the receiving party to instantaneously return or destroy documents on request. This is an unreasonable timeframe.
